title: skip flakey blockOnResponse tests
body:
`workbench.action.chat.open.blockOnResponse` is flaking in CI. So far,
I cannot reproduce locally so skipping to avoid noise in CI while I
debug.

Since the core logic (i.e. not the test) is only hit if `blockOnResponse`
is set to `true`, leaving it in is low-risk.

Relates #263572.
Relates #263575.

title: Providing permissions to chat-participant extension in vscode/test-cli
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
## Note
Reopen of issue [#263491](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/263491) because bot tagged it as duplicate of [#253137](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/253137), but I do not think it is a firewall issue.  My assumption regular functionality requires extension permission, but in test environment it is impossible to provide.
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->
# Original request
There is no way to authorize extension access to LM API from @vscode/test-cli.  
Reports `LanguageModelError: Language model 'copilot/gpt-4.1' cannot be used by 'vscode-samples.chat-sample-v2'. at As.NoPermissions` but there is no way to provide permissions/authentication programmatically (that I am aware of)

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.31.2025082602
- VS Code Version: 
```
Version: 1.104.0-insider (user setup)
Commit: 2db7aa70ee3e250a2fcdb4dbbd85dd524d2fb7a2
Date: 2025-08-22T05:03:22.299Z
Electron: 37.2.3
ElectronBuildId: 12035395
Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.22631
```
- OS Version: Windows 11
- Feature: ASK Mode with custom Chat Participant (@cat) from [vscode-extension-samples](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/tree/main/chat-sample)
- Selected model: GPT 4.1
- Select Logs:

```
  1) Chat Participant Direct Function Test
       Test chat participant handler logic directly:
     LanguageModelError: Language model 'copilot/gpt-4.1' cannot be used by 'vscode-samples.chat-sample-v2'.
        at As.NoPermissions (file:///c:/Users/e177596/Downloads/chat-sample/.vscode-test/vscode-win32-x64-archive-1.103.2/resources/app/out/vs/workbench/api/node/extensionHostProcess.js:107:62326)
        at sy.p (file:///c:/Users/e177596/Downloads/chat-sample/.vscode-test/vscode-win32-x64-archive-1.103.2/resources/app/out/vs/workbench/api/node/extensionHostProcess.js:114:29352)
        at async Context.<anonymous> (c:\Users\e177596\Downloads\chat-sample\out\test\suite\directFunctionTest.test.js:64:30)
```

Steps to Reproduce:

1. CD to `chat-sample` example code: npm install
2. Add vscode/test-cli test to call LM (in test `const response = await availableModel.sendRequest(messages, {}, new vscode.CancellationTokenSource().token);
` 
```ts
import { defineConfig } from '@vscode/test-cli';

export default defineConfig({
    files: 'out/test/**/*.test.js',
    version: 'stable',
    workspaceFolder: './sampleWorkspace',
    extensionDevelopmentPath: './',
    reuseMachineInstall: true,
    mocha: {
        ui: 'tdd',
        timeout: 120000, // Extended timeout for user authentication and Language Model calls
        color: true
    },
    launchArgs: [
        '--disable-extension-update-checks',
        '--disable-telemetry',
        '--disable-crash-reporter' 
    ]
});
```
3. Run `npm test`
4. Authorize Github Copilot in Isolated Environ before test starts
5. See log result

Full Log below:
```
$ npm test

> chat-sample-v2@0.1.0 test
> vscode-test

⠋ Resolving version...(node:22752) Warning: Setting the NODE_TLS_REJECT_UNAUTHORIZED environment variable to '0' makes TLS connections and HTTPS requests insecure by disabling certificate verification.
(Use `node --trace-warnings ...` to show where the warning was created)

title: Setting `terminal.integrated.minimumContrastRatio` to 1 not stopping dim colours from changing
body:
Type: Bug Bassically, setting `"terminal.integrated.minimumContrastRatio": 1` does not stop VS code's integrated terminal from changing the colour of "dim" text (i.e. with ANSI `\e[2m`) from changing based on the background: This is what Windows Terminal is showing: This is what VS Code is showing with `"terminal.integrated.minimumContrastRatio": 1` (the dim text on the black background is all the same colour as Windows Terminal): This is what VS code is showing using the default `terminal.integrated.minimumContrastRatio` setting: Basically I want to make my VS Code terminal look the same as Windows Terminal (since I switch between the two frequently). I also don't like colours changing when I didn't ask for it! ### Test file just go `echo -e $(cat testfile)` to test: ``` \e[40m \e[0m\e[100m \e[0m \e[41m \e[0m\e[101m \e[0m \e[42m \e[0m\e[102m \e[0m title: VSC merge editor will not work properly for files added in both branches

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Type: Bug 1. From your main branch create two new branches. In both branches add a file with the same name but with some small difference that will cause a merge conflict. 2. Attempt to merge and resolve the conflict in the Merge Editor. 3. Notice that it's impossible to complete the merge with the Merge Editor. You can just run this pwsh script which will reproduce this state: ```pwsh # Init repo and commit something to branch off of git init merge-editor-bug && cd ./merge-editor-bug git checkout -b main echo "" | Set-Content "example.txt" git add . git commit -m "init" # Create conflicting file in two branches git checkout -b foo @" lorem ipsum foo dolor sit amet "@ | Set-Content lorem.txt git add . git commit -m "foo" git checkout main git checkout -b bar @" lorem ipsum bar dolor sit amet "@ | Set-Content lorem.txt git add . git commit -m "bar" # Merge and check merge editor git merge foo code . # Open the merge changes for lorem.txt in the source control tab. # Observe that git correctly marked lines 2 as conflicting. # Press "Resolve in Merge Editor". # VS Code will mark the entire file content as current/incoming. # The button "Complete Merge" will not appear regardless of what you accept. ``` VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

title: API accessibility for copilot in VSCode
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Here’s our situation: we have Copilot Enterprise, which limits us to using Copilot only on our own code—a restriction I suspect many users encounter.

Copilot works extremely well, and we would like to integrate it into our CI/CD pipeline. Since GitHub Copilot does not provide a direct API, I’d love to be able to spin up an instance of VS Code on a CI server, send prompts to Copilot, and have Copilot make code changes in agent mode, followed by a git add and push.

This setup would allow us to leverage Copilot in CI to perform automated AI-driven code prompts and “fixes,” which developers could then review.

It might be a somewhat hacky approach, but I’m open to suggestions for a better way to achieve this.

title: Vscode can't find custom C++ modules

labels.name: *caused-by-extension
labels.description: Issue identified to be caused by an extension

body:
Type: Bug I wanted to test C++ 20 modules (On C++ 23), and so I followed the guides and info here: - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/cpp/modules-cpp?view=msvc-170 - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/cpp/tutorial-import-stl-named-module?view=msvc-170 I got the std library module to compile and link correctly following that. At first intelliSense was angry and Vscode prompted me to change the Configuration Provider to Cmake Tools. I did that and the errors were gone. Then I decided to add a custom module (test_module.ixx) with a couple functions for coverting degrees <-> radians. I extended the CMakeLists.txt file to add the custom module to the sources and everything compiled correctly but i get the following error: "could not find module file for module "test_module"C/C++(3275)". I'm running the latest MSVC compiler for amd64 (17.14.13). I've looked everywhere but couldn't find any (non-ancient) issues or PRs related to this other than some related to Visual Studio. Directory structure: This is my current CMakeLists.txt file: ```CMake cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.30) project(ModulesProject LANGUAGES CXX) set(CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD 23) set(CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD_REQUIRED ON) set(CMAKE_CXX_SCAN_FOR_MODULES ON) # This automagically includes some required .dlls from msvc set(CMAKE_MSVC_RUNTIME_LIBRARY "MultiThreaded$<$:Debug>") add_executable(ModulesProject) target_sources( ModulesProject PUBLIC main.cpp PUBLIC FILE_SET CXX_MODULES FILES test_module.ixx ) target_include_directories(ModulesProject PRIVATE "${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/") set_target_properties(ModulesProject PROPERTIES RUNTIME_OUTPUT_DIRECTORY "${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}") target_compile_options(ModulesProject PRIVATE /reference "std=${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/std.ifc") target_compile_options(ModulesProject PRIVATE /nologo /std:c++latest) ``` VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

title: Display number of files next to number of references for References Code Lens

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: typescript
labels.description: Typescript support issues

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

> [!NOTE]
> search terms: codelens, code lens, references code lens, number of files, typescript.referencesCodeLens

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

I'd like the "References Code Lens" to also display **the number of files** in which the function is referenced.

Sometimes the number of references alone is not too helpful, because a function can be used in a single context (class, function) multiple times -- which makes refactoring rather easy, and sometimes it can be used in multiple contexts once -- which makes refactoring harder. Or sometimes the other way round, you know how it's like. My point is that the number of files can be a helpful additional information that lets you quickly assess the impact of potential modifications.

I'd see this either as a separate setting, next to `typescript.referencesCodeLens.enabled` (e.g. `typescript.referencesCodeLens.show[NumberOf]Files`, or it could be a non-configurable addition to the existing feature. 

Before:


_5 references_
**public async getAll()**


After:


_5 references, 2 files_
**public async getAll()**

title: Add opt-in preference to auto-execute Copilot suggested terminal commands and auto-continue long responses

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

## Problem
When interacting with GitHub Copilot in VS Code, the assistant sometimes:
- suggests running terminal commands and shows a "Run" or "Continue" button, or
- truncates long responses and shows a "Continue / Iterate" action to generate more.

Currently the user must click the action each time. For workflows where users trust Copilot and want minimal friction (e.g., scaffolding, repeated small edits, iterative refactors), having to manually click reduces productivity.

## Proposal
Add configurable, opt-in settings that allow users to:
1. Automatically run Copilot-suggested terminal commands when the assistant shows a runnable command.
2. Automatically continue / iterate generation when the response length reaches a limit.

Both features should be disabled by default and have granular controls and safety checks.

### Suggested settings (names are suggestions)
```json
"github.copilot.autoRunSuggestedCommands": false,
"github.copilot.autoContinueLongResponses": false,
"github.copilot.autoRun.confirmationForDangerousCommands": true,
"github.copilot.autoRun.commandWhitelist": ["npm install", "dotnet restore"]

body: - Copilot Chat Extension Version: 1.362.1760 - VS Code Version: 1.104.0-Insider - OS Version: mac - Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): code review - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): . - Logs: ``` 2025-08-27 15:10:31.437 [info] [github review agent] coding guidelines request id: E224:30B222:912D1:BB1EA:68AEA157 2025-08-27 15:10:31.437 [info] Failed to fetch coding guidelines for ~~/~~: ``` Steps to Reproduce: When multiple GitHub accounts are linked within VS Code, attempting to use the Code Review feature on local changes in the Source Control view for a repository owned by the other linked account results in an HTTP 500 error. The logs suggest a failure in fetching repository-specific coding guidelines, which may be due to an authentication or permission conflict between the two accounts. 1. Configure VS Code by signing into both Account A (with Copilot) and Account B (repo owner). 2. Clone and open a repository that is owned by Account B. 3. Make some local code changes to one or more files. 4. Navigate to the Source Control view. 5. In the "Changes" section, click the "Code Review" button to review the pending changes. 6. Observe the error.

body: Our perf bots show a sizeable increase in startup time to load the main bundle: This is the time from `performance.timeOrigin` until the very first line of code executes in `main.ts`: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/d1283528189526b8fea024ce7330dd90335ee9cb/src/main.ts#L25-L31 The range seems to be: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/compare/0361f9c36f28990d8527c03d720b803c7cb4883d...986f8e6054200db6e8215bbcb216f3cd2429eb4d I see 2 commits that are maybe impacting this, mainly by looking at changes that impact `electron-main` or `node` or `utility-process`: * https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/262546 * https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/262558

title: Chat session view loads every time you switch to it
body:
1. Switch to the chat session view and let it load
2. Switch to the explorer so the session view is hidden
3. Switch back to the session view

**Bug**
I see a loading indicator on the `Github coding agent` section

Instead I think we should only load it once and then rely on the provider the trigger updates

title: Editor looks broken when loading chat session
body: 1. Load a chat session for the first time **bug** The editor is very empty so it always looks kind of broken to me in this state: Besides the progress bar, could we show a loading message / additional skeleton UI for the chat history area during loading?

title: Speed up `NativeEditContext _updateSelectionAndControlBounds` for cases when a lot of editors are created

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

body: As part of #263499, I'm trying to speed up rendering of chat responses. When a response contains a large number of code blocks, we end up creating a large number of editors for it. One slow part of this is the `NativeEditContext. _updateSelectionAndControlBounds` call after the editor is created Here you can see a few of these calls: This call is slow because it forces a recalculate styles + relayout In my regular chat session log, we end up spending several hundred ms just on these calls when you first open the session log: Would it be possible to avoid this call until there is a hint the NativeContext is needed, such as the editor becoming focused?
